text: the key to any gnocchi and the key to
many foods is balance but here where you
have the basis is cheese's ricotta
cheese and Parmesan cheese what you need
is to find a way to hold those together
now you could just dump in a ton of
flour and some eggs and now you could
glue anything together with flour and
eggs but then they become heavy they've
become like bad matzo balls so the idea
is to find the balance of the least
possible amount of flour that will bind
thought of cut though so this is a 15
ounce container of ricotta 2 eggs
songs shell and about a cup and a half
of parmesan it's a lot of parmesan but
ricotta is very very bland and you need
some flavor you want some flavor in here
with a large pinch of salt
despite the parmesan and a little bit of
pepper now obviously if you put that in
boiling water tried to do anything with
it it would fall apart immediately so
this is why we need some flour and we're
using just a cup you can use 3/4 of a
cup of flour
when yucky won't crumble in the water
but they will start shedding little bits
of themselves so a little bit at a time
blend it in well our sauce which I could
start now is going to be browned butter
beurre noisette nut butter with a lot of
sage in it salted just simmering water a
nice rounded tablespoon and it should
sink and when it's done it'll rise to
the top ok the butter as you can see is
nicely browned we're gonna throw in some
sage leaves and turn that off for now
you can take them at at that point put
them in a baking dish reheat them later
with the sauce on top or you could just
eat them then in there
and even more parmesan
so good
